reviewText:
I'm changing my review slightly to better fit with my thoughts, especially considering the most recent DLCs/patches in this.

This game I really and truly feel was balanced specifically for people who like to break systems, or who enjoy a more balanced gameplay experience (I.E multiplayer). EUIII in comparison I felt, while rather easy (which was not a problem to me, but I do know people for whom it was) in its ease allowed for a lot of fun and ahistorical scenarios, EUIV's dedication to its idea of 'balance,' where every country has this strength and this weakness and every country is forced into these very historical highways that do not allow for fun deviations without missing out on a -massive- power advantage by strictly following history I just don't find fun.

There are also problems like the military aspect, especially early game, being the realm of the larger powers. You essentially know whether you have won or lost a war before it even begins, as if you don't have a major power on your side, or you yourself aren't, you're screwed. Even if they don't start out the war with one on their side, the scales are tipped in the defenders favor in a conflict to an insane degree. You can ally up with people and call them into defensive wars mid war. You can have people intercede on your behalf for a white peace without even giving two ♥♥♥♥♥ about your country.

All of this means that trying to turn someone like Poland or even a relatively decent power like Venice into a world hegemony is ridiculously difficult as your manpower issues and your forced historical focus keeps you, ironically enough, from doing some things that may have in fact happened historically that just don't fit the narrative of the country according to Paradox.

If you want a strategy game thats a challenge with some decent window trimming of the time period I think EUIV will do you fine. If you want a game that properly dedicates itself to allowing you the freedom to make a country and mold it in this time period according to your weird kingly whims, EUIII is still the much better product IMO.
voteText: 37 of 63 people (59%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has had so much potential but it has failed to become the great game I thought it should be. This is because of a few things.

1) Balance
2) DLC
3) Stupid leave game system
4) Botched alliance and favour system
5) Coalitions

First of all the balance, this game has the entire world for you to play as but most of time will be in europe. Why? Well faster gameplay stronger units on average as well as more and bigger events than anywhere else. This leads to the balance complaint. First of all if Castille decides to it can easily conquer most of Northern Africa then inherit Aragon and possible Naples very early game. Meaning they can quickly expand into Italy and lower parts of Africa. This then leads to the alliances complaint as it is entirely possible for Castille to have both Austria and France as allies meaning the main defence for Africa (Ottoman Empire) is not going to last very long especially with Poland and Lithuania glaring at them as well. A united India would struggle to push back a European power as well.

The DLC in this game while it did come out very slowly and only the host needs it is a gauling ammount. Another complaint with this is the unbalancing that Common Sense originally brought with it which if not purchased allowed the AI to develop their provinces making them much better while you couldn't without the DLC. The alliance system in the Cossacks was a step in the right direction for curbing the use of powerful nations for rapid expansion but it does not seem to have an option for 'I am attacking your rival, please help me curb their power', which I have found it to be rather annoying. Some of the features do feel like they should have been in the base game anyway such as the ability to swap occupations which came with the art of war DLC.

More of an annoyance than an actual complaint but the game shuts down briefly and reloads if you quit the game you were in. At least it is a step forward from the previous method of locking you out of multiplayer if you were going to go play with a friend.

The alliance system as mentioned before does need some work still. This because you can have all the powerful nations in the same area all allied with each other which basically means game over. I have seen this with Scandanavia - France - Commonwealth which was proberly the most annoying, Russia - Ottomans - Austria - Papal State, this one was daft. Britain - Austria - Castille - Aragon, is a more recent one I have seen. I would say this makes it interesting but they will quickly become immortal and just keep expanding everywhere.

The coalition system, now this is a huge pain. Largely because the AI never seem to get them. I have seen France take over huge portions of land in Germany in single wars and not have any back lash for it. Normally it is measured through development but since it is Germany the average values are quite high and can easily cause a coalition. I have taken 3 provinces and caused a world war to kick off over it.

reviewText:
You are the King/Queen/Parician/Doge/Empoerer/Empress/Chief/Sultan of any nation that existed as a soveign state inbetween the years of 1444-1821. Be it the Ottoman Empire, or the start of the Austrian Empire, the world is in your hands the moment you start off. There are no limits to potential ambitions and goals, and achievements give you some good starting(and also very hard) goals for you to try out in your spare time. Restore the Roman Empire from the remnants of the once great Byzantines, barely holding onto Constantinople itself. Restore Danish Hegemony over the Baltic by defeating Sweden. Create an Albanian empire in the Balkans. Form an Iroquious Confederacy controlling all of Eastern North America. Unite Japan and take the pacific as your birthright.

There are no limits to the possabilities this game brings to the table if you like history, or just strategy gameplay in general. Managing a global empire is no easy task, however. Colonies will want freedom, trade companies will exploit the native population, and soon... Perhaps even a revolution from the inside of your own capital?

Pros:
- Massive replayability with hundreds of potential nations.
- Most of earth at your grasp.
- Many potential routes to take, from conquest to diplomacy to trade.
- Theres a gothic nation in the Crimea, CONQUER THE WORLD AS THE LAST GOTHIC PEOPLE!
- Actually good multiplayer support.
- EXTREAMLY GOOD MODDING COMMUNITY!

Cons:
- Steep heftly learning curve that can take hours, sometimes day to get through.
- No one wants to hear about you conquering Russia as the goths.
- Sweden is not overpowered.

reviewText:
Taking what Europa Universalis III did right and making it better, EUIV has become an intense struggle to build a vast empire in any area across Earth. Want to construct a grand African nation to fight off potenital European colonizers? How about founding a vast Venetian trade empire, capable of supplying arms to rebels of your enemies? Want to restore the Roman Empire to its former glory and repair the schism of the church? Perhaps you're interesting in colonizing and exploiting the Americas as much as possible? Maybe there's a chance of China forming a large army and marching on their enemies in India and Europe?

Then do it.

That's how intricate and complex (or simple, if you like it that way) this game can get. If you like Grand Strategy games and have an interest in history, this game is for you. No doubt about it.

reviewText:
It has been a long, long time since I got this genuinely excited about a game. It even got to the point where friends and acquaintances were remarking that maybe I should calm down when I talked about it. The last time I got this riled up about a game I was playing Shogun: Total War for the first time.

Europa Universalis is a game that really took my by surprise. Yes, that was pretty much due to my ignorance of the series. But I feel like I discovered a masterpiece. Everything within the game just gels so well together it creates the grandest of experiences on so large and so long a scale no game can really match it in what it has set out to do. No game even really can try to match since they all focus on victory. Europa focuses on playing the game, its focuses on riding the waves of history through both its high points and its low points. Can you survive the ebb and flow of time?

If you are so inclined you can find my full review of the game over at my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/05/europa-universalis-iv.html.

reviewText:
Change history the way you see fit.

Unlike most games of its kind, Europa doesn't focus only on world domination. Your nation can easily prosper from trade, technology, religion, or any number of factors.

The diplomacy is something to be admired, considering it stops you from being a warmongering menace to the world. If you really want to conquer the world, expect complete resistance and harsh penalties for doing so.

Even if this game was barebones and lacked good content (which it doesn't), it comes with Workshop. As with any Workshop game, there's endless possibilities on how you can modify your game to your heart's content.

With easy-to-use multiplayer connection, play with your friends for just as long as you'd play alone.

If the price is stopping you from buying this game, don't let it. If you love strategy, this will be one of your best purchases on Steam.

reviewText:
It's difficult to say whether I'd recommend EUIV as it is now or not- especially since I see more of its faults than its good points. Fortunately, as with a lot of Paradox titles, recent updates have been increasingly making the game better than what it originally was. While some changes have been poorly received and needed adjustment later (Paradox's newfound popularity has also come with a much larger number of people only familiar with EUIV and CK2 giving feedback upon yonder forums.) Paradox seems to have found a direction that properly takes (good) player feedback into account, without relying upon it too heavily.

It's not quite the game I wanted it to be, with some mechanics changes simplifying the game in a negative way (restoring stability with the push of a button when you have sufficient points is far too simple.) and other EUIII mechanics remaining that are only hurting the current state of the game. (Missions are terribly outdated things which can hardly be said to function in the current state of the game.)

Despite all this, it's still a very fun, easy to play game. Perhaps with some more updates (and a few mods...) I'll be able to say EUIV is a masterpiece of a grand strategy game.

reviewText:
So I'm Korea. I started out just trying to give myself a buffer and taking a little land to the north. Nothing big, just a parcel. But taking land is like crack, you just need to take a little more to get your fix. Before I know it, Japan hates me (big surprise there), China's annoyed with me, and Russia's encroaching on my nether regions. So for a twist on history, this time, I make Japan MY ho. And ho she became. I colonized Indonesia, colonized Taiwan, took a little land here and a lot more there. Eventually I'm strong enough to hang with the big boys of the East. Ming dynasty? More like queen dynasty. I shattered her face. Next thing I know, I have France, Spain, and Russia colonizing my doorstep. Me and France? Yeah, we're cool. But Europe can be a real jerk sometimes..

2nd world problems...

10/10

reviewText: I know this game has plenty of fans.  It has incredibly complicated diplomatic and military dynamics that undoubtedly give an intesnely realistic experience to what is fundamentally a war game (think risk on steroids).  If you're willing to invest many, many hours of complete and utter failure in an attempt to learn the intricacies of the game, you'll surely enjoy it.  Unlike every other strategy game I've played there is truly no learning" mode.  There's no option to dial down the difficulty level while you figure out game play.  It's trial by fire
date: and I hate to admit I spent so many hours on this more out of determination to figure out how not to get crushed than any sense of fun."

reviewText:
How to play Byzcan'tine Empire:

Attempt 1: Get Poland as ally but Lithuania PU never fires. Check Austria diplo and it's a minor in a PU with Aragon 2 years into the game.

Attempt 2: Ottomans ignore you for 15 years and blob literally everything in Asia Minor and all minors in Balkans. Poland then dishonors call to defensive war against Ottomans for no obvious reason (not already in a war etc.).

Attempt 3: Ottomans declare war before you can get any allies.

Attempt 4: Hungary white peaces out while Ottomans are also majorly losing a war with Mamluks on the other end. Ottomans then wreck you.

Attempt 5: Game starts out good. Within three years of game start your ruler dies and a rebel pretender much stronger than you stack wipes your army and takes Constantinople.

Attempt 6: Game starts out good. Within four years of game start your ruler dies and a rebel pretender much stronger than you stack wipes your army and takes Constantinople.

Attempt 7: Game starts out good. Within two years of game start your ruler dies and a rebel pretender much stronger than you stack wipes your army and takes Constantinople.

Attempt 8: Everything set up nice with Polish/Lithuania ally. Wardec Ottomans and Poland/Lithuania get completely destroyed due to generals literally rolling eternal 0's and 1's. Ottomans stack wipes everything they look at with fewer troops, worse generals and with crossing penalties.

Attempt 9: Poland and Hungary are rivals. You decide to try again game hasn't even started yet.

Attempt 10: Poland and Hungary are rivals. You decide to try again game hasn't even started yet.

Attempt 11: Poland and Hungary are rivals. You decide to try again game hasn't even started yet.

Attempt 12: You decide the fourth rivalry in a row may not be a bad thing if you try an Austria alliance again. Improve relations with all 3 anyway. Can't get diplo high enough to ally Austria (stops at -13 with no other options). Ottomans wardec before you can ally Poland.


10/10 would play Groundhog's Day Simulator 2016 again

reviewText: As far as Grand Strategy style games, this is one of the best out there. A lot of micromanagement for those who enjoy it, and a good deal of features and fun game play. I'd be lying if I said I wouldn't like to have the ability to actually control battles that occur like in Total War, but this is far more detailed when it comes to governing and economics. reviewText:
This game will take hours off of your life (in the best way possible).

Europa Universalis IV [EU4] is a grand strategy RTS from Paradox Interactive. The game is set on the earth anywhere within 1444-1825, focusing heavily on colonization, imperialism and the influence of the papacy and the Holy Roman Empire on the rest of the known world at the time.

I don't think I've ever fallen so completely in love with a game since I discovered the Metroid series. One of the things that bug me about RTS games is that usually, during the late game, there isn't much to do since your economy is self-sustaining and the most attention-consuming task is managing military units. EU4 goes so much more in depth than any other game I've played before (to be fair, it is my first grand strategy game, so I don't know how it compares to its peers).

I like to always have my mind focused on something and can get bored quite easily at times. While there are slow times like in any other game, EU4 has so many little tasks and situations that need occasional checking up, as well as random events every so often, that your mind is almost always engaged.

The learning curve is quite steep for this game, in my own experience (around 20-30 hours to grasp many of the subtle yet critical elements). I recommend starting as the Aztecs for your first game - no one in Central America can build ships for quite a while, so you will be able to focus on understanding how the basics of land combat work. You will be defeated multiple times your first few playthroughs. Don't give up - this is quite normal. Also, turn player bonuses on in the menu for your first few learning games.

I won't go into detail on the elements of the game since there are SO MANY - this review would probably take about 20-30 min to read if I did and nobody likes that :/

If you need help learning the game, the in-game tutorial didn't do much for me. I hear there are superb video tutorials on YouTube, so check those out if you so desire.

As for DLC, there are currently five official expansions and numerous music/cosmetic enhancements. I have purchased a few of the music/cosmetics and cannot complain, but I have not purchased any of the expansions and so cannot comment on their value.

I have used the Extended Timeline mod extensively and completely recommend that you try it, but play some vanilla games first since it is essentially a complete overhaul.

I have lost much time to this game. Whether or not that is good is for you to decide. I wholeheartedly recommend this masterpiece to anyone who claims to enjoy strategy gaming.

+ FIVE THUMBS UP +
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Quite possibly my favorite strategy game of all time. You pick a nation from any time between the 15th century to the 19th and play as them, making allies, fighting wars, discovering the Americas, whatever you choose. Although it sacrifices some of the complexity of it's older sibling, Crusader Kings II, it manages to improve gameplay all across the board, at the heart of which is the flexible negotiations, where you can not only choose what to win or lose when settling a peace depending on who has been winning the war, but you can also negotiate separate truces with any secondary members of the war, letting them go easy to weaken your main enemy or crushing them one by one and making them rue the day they ever dared challenge you. And the best part? There is a free demo.

reviewText: EU4 has turned out to be the best strategy game I have ever played.  Just a warning, the learning curve is massive.  If you think Sim City or Civilization is difficult to learn, you should not play EU4.  The game is not much in the way of graphical showcasing, but it makes up for that with the thousands of real-time modifiers happening in the world.  Strategy really matters in this game and there is a very active forum & wiki community to help figure out what you might not notice (did i metion thousands of modifiers?).  The developers are also active in the community and have been releasing DLCs and patches to evolve the game as the player base becomes more 'intellegent'.  The Multiplayer community can be hit or miss, since it takes a lot of dedication and time to get a game to the finish of 1821. The game is inifinitely more fun in multiplayer since the AI is predictable after a while.

reviewText: EU4 is a great grand strategy game and has vastly improved since release. Paradox Interactive regularly adds new free content along with every dlc they make and the dlc adds some great features that are worth the price. EU4 is very fun once your into it but it takes quite a bit of learning to get into it and one of its faults is the tutorials lack of help when it comes to learning the game. If you are interested in this game and haven't played a Paradox Interactive grand strategy game I would highly reccomend watching some people play it on Youtube since it really helps you learn the game better. This game does a great job of allowing to conquer the world however you want with any country in the game. Yet world conquest isn't the only way to win as you can focus on a colonial trade power, unifying the Holy Roman Empire, or many different ways to play. Highly recommended game if you enjoy grand strategy games and if you have a remote interest go watch it on Youtube to find out more about it.

reviewText: You pick a country. You change history. It's fun.\n\nIn all seriousness, Europa Universalis IV is an amazing game. It's variety of gameplay allowing you to be a one-city merchant nation or a nation that can potentially conquer the entirety of the inhabitable planet allows for many strategies and play styles. The game has streamlined since EU3, but for the better. When most games claim to streamline they really just mean dumbing down mechanics to reach a broad audience, but Paradox knows that wouldn't work. Their playerbase is far too devoted to allow that. In fact, the game expands in many important areas, such as ideas and warfare. While there isn't many surface layer improvements from EU3, the game definitely did a lot of much needed tweaking under the hood. This game is a must-have for fans of grand strategy.

reviewText:
Extremely fun game. Much better with friends but still great alone.
I used to play the Total War series games but once I switched over to Europa Universalis I won't be going back to TW games. I did enjoy the TW series but the diplomacy of TW series is broken. Everyone always hate you for no reason.
EU diplomacy is much more advanced. If someone hates you, there is a reason and it even tells you what that reason is. You don't just get back stabbed from an ally in EU.

Game with all the DLCs is a bit overpriced. I do enjoy the DLCs but I feel they shouldn't have costed as much as they do. Playing the game without DLCs feels like playing an incomplete version of the game.

The ability to MOD the game adds much more replay value to it which is a huge plus.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the leaders of Grand Strategy Games genre. You must guide your nation of choice to world dominance through conquest, diplomacy and colonization. Controls are pleasantly abstracted - for example, when you dicover a new kind of military unit, you can upgrade all your armies with 1 click. There's little to none micro managment, you can devise your sophisticated plot and relax in your chair as you can setup a full scale invasion with just a few clicks. Game is visually appealing, though, in my opinion, EU would look better with 2D graphics (instead of full 3d).

There's only one thing that i really dislike about this game - the combat resolution. It has very sophisticated algorithm with dozens of parameters. It's very vague and as a player you have absolutely no idea what the hell is happening unless you invest an ~hour of researching on the internets.

All in all EU4 is one of the top games in its genre. It's equally good for people who love Grand Strategies and as an entry point for people who are curious about the genre and want to try it.

9/10 would buy to rule the world.
voteText: 17 of 28 people (61%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Madly addictive, interesting and intricate. Infuriating at the same time, when larger kingdoms wipe out your army in an instant and then without restraint lay seige to your whole country. This dispair is offset by the complete joy of colonizing new lands and investing in more and more advanced societies and technology. A great insight into the time of it's setting. Promising to be far less frustrating when the 'Art of War' expansion comes out. Should be less instances of your supposed allies, sitting there watching you get demolished by your enemies before being defeated themselves...

Visuals/Audio 3/5
Optimisation/Quality 4/5
Replayability 5/5
Value for Money 3/5
Immersion/Fun 4/5
OVERALL 4/5

reviewText:
EU4 continues the greatness of the EU series, this time with the updated engine seen in CK2.  If you own both games and have the CK2-EU4 converter, you can now lead your empire for almost a millennium!

Back in EU4, you can once again choose from hundreds of historical nations around the world.  From the start, you will work to lead your country through history.  You can begin in the New World and try to fight off the European invaders, try to unite Japan or keep the Ottoman empire from falling apart.  This grand strategy game is a must if you enjoy trying to change the course of history.

reviewText:
This Game is Great, it is one of the best strategy games ever.
There is just this one thing... They make an update about every month (or so) and it always completely destroys the game. It makes the game completely unplayable after that and you almost have to buy the latest DLC cause otherwise it is just completely unplayable... and they are not cheap...

reviewText:
This game is a big surprise for me this year. I never though i will enjoy it so much since I havent played any Paradox games before. This has to be because unlike Total War series Paradoxes games doesnt look attractive at all :D, but when i started playing this i couldn't get my hands off it, its so addictive.

I have long been a Total War series fan and i still like some of their games but this game is in many ways way superior than any TW game - modded or not. Unlike Rome TW 2 this game is imo one of the most well though games i ever played, and i will be easily putting hundreds of hours in, and enjoying every moment of it.
The complexity of whole system may seem huge at first but its worth to invest some time in understaning it, since it will be returned to you tenfold.

Many thanks to Goro and others who persuaded me to buy this game ;D

Final verdict 10/10, my GOTY :D

reviewText:
My first experience of Europa Universalis IV was a mixed experience. I bought the game on the advice of a friend, and played a multiplayer game with him. I picked the Ottoman Empire -- as the game recommended -- and proceeded to build what I thought was a decent empire primarily through militarism. I swept through eastern Europe and western Asia with ease and controlled everything from the east of Poland to the west of India.

As the game progressed, however, I began to lose control of my land to the newly formed Russia and to Poland. It turned out that, because I hadn't understood the game, I hadn't kept my military tech up to date or westernized. I love depth in games, but the frustration of losing large parts of my empire before the game's end because of a misunderstanding of priorities put me off, and I shelved the game for a while.

Later on, in one of my periods of watching a lot of Let's Play" videos

reviewText:
I think that Europa Universalis IV is the best grand strategy game out there. I used to be a great Total War fan and one day i saw a friend of mine playing europa and he started explaining me how did it work. I was fascinated so bought it and tried it out: AMAZING.

I can just say that you can take the role of a country/kingdom/whatever from all over the world, from European countries, african tribes, asiatic empires or even the japanese clans/shogunate. Choose what you want and throw yourself in an epic quest starting from 1444 and ending in 1750.

I HIGHLY SUGGEST IT. 5/5.

reviewText: When I was in Afghanistan I bought EU3 as a time killer. Now I really really really really REALLY sucked at that game, Infact I still couldnt play it properly after trying for weeks because the learning curve on that game was as steep as Mt. Everest yet I enjoyed ever second of it. When EU4 was released I was excited and also intemidated based on my previous experince with EU3. I can now say after playing 80 hours, EU4 is just as fun as EU3 and is so much easier to learn. Even though it still took me about 20-30 hours to learn the game, once you climb that learning curve youll be humbled by just the amount choices you have in directing where your country will go. I highly reccommend this game to anybody who likes strategy games just be warned, If you're a Total War fan or a Civ fan those games will never be the same after playing EU4.\n\nEDIT: Those 80 hours were only spent playing as three different factions (western countries at that). I still have yet to try out the colonist part of the the game, let alone play as a muslim, horde, indian, chinese, japanese, or meso-american faction.

reviewText:
While the game has given me several hundred hours of enjoyment, and it still has the fun of taking a one provence minor and making them the most feared power in the world, I wouldn't recommend this game. Lots of small annoying changes from EU3, like the monarch points system and inabilty to control the advisors you get, make the game feel very irritating to someone familiar with older Paradox grand strategy games.

I would whole heartedly recommened EU3 or CK2 over this game, at least in its vanilla state, for more enjoyable times.

Also the multiplayer while adding at interesting human element to the game, can tend to move VERY slowly as you are forced to play on a slow speed and there is much less mirco, or small things, that need to be done in this game.

reviewText: At the behest of a friend, I decided to pick up Europa Universalis IV. I had never played it and did not know anything about the game when I grabbed it as part of a humble bundle deal. I assumed from the title, as well as the cover photo's of the game, it would be much like Civilization or Tropico, with a historical slant. What I found is, Europa Universalis IV has much more in common with Crusader Kings. You build up your territories, similar to the way you would in Civ, but you are given the opportunity to micro-manage your country, down to the last detail of what religion they will be. The array of starting countries is not limited to Europe and Asia, you can even start out as a Native American tribe in the yet to be discovered, New World". Europa Universalis IV

reviewText: Europa Universalis IV gives the player an immensely fast-paced, low learning curve gameplay experience. Have you every wanted to know what it felt like to be Napoleon, Willem van Oranje or Mary, Queen of Scots? Then this is the game for you! Definitely something to recommend to younger people, considering it's so easy to get in to the game. No explaining or tutorial required. Conquering the world has never been more relaxing or satisfying, no rage quits guaranteed! This is all made possible because of the intuitive nature of the game. Everything just makes sense, it's amazing! What are you waiting for? Play a game of EU4!

reviewText:
Russia colonizing Australia because screw Great Britain, Sweden ruling Northern Germany and Canada because screw Great Britain, Rebelling as the USA (although not exciting as the real War for American Independance) because screw Great Britain, Create the world's largest trade hegemony as Portugal because screw the Netherlands for a change, or Byzantium re-emerging from a near-dead with the help of Poland to kick the Ottoman's butt. What's not to love about totally messing up history?

However, this is more than your average strategy game. If you're coming from the Civ camp over here, you're going to have a hard time. Trading, diplomacy, and war are a lot deeper here from other strategy games. I reccomend watching a let's play on YouTube after playing the tutorial, otherwise you're gonna suck at this.

All in all this is a great game for experienced strategy masters with great paths towards alternate history. Once you play it any other non-Paradox game will seem extremely slow and boring.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Europa Universalis IV is the fourth grand strategy game about the awkward puberty between the medieval era and the industrial revolution from Paradox Development Studios. It has a lot to live up to considering the success of their last two major titles, Europa Universalis III and Crusader Kings II.

So does it live up to it? Ultimately I think so. It streamlines many of the aspects of EUIII and CKII that turned away many novice strategy lovers. Recruiting soldiers is easier, the Trade system is more intuitive than before and the game really makes an effort to encourage the possibility of a mostly peaceful game, which is good because it feels good to switch it up every once in awhile.

Not that it's eazy to run out of things to do in EUIV. You can choose literally any nation in existence on any day in between 1444 and 1821, and although some are less fleshed out than others because they played a lesser role in history, the fact that there are so many options is by itself astounding.

Overall, I give EUIV a 9.1 out 0f 10. I haven't fleshed out all the reasons in this review why it is so worth your 40 dollars, but just rest assured it is totally worth that amount (although I'd still reccommend waiting for the inevitable sale.).
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This was my first expedition into EU territory, and let me tell you that all the dials, buttons, modifiers and events are rather overwhelming at first. However the game comes with fairly good tutorials but I'd say the two best ways to learn how to fully play EU4 is to watch someone on Youtube like Enter Elysium and to start your first game as a large nation like England or Castille (Spain).

To be honest I have played this game for quite a while and still haven't got a full grasp on some of the little details, but I  love playing EU4. It is a notoriously hard game in Iron man mode where you have to live with your decisions and the random number generated events that can help you or kill you, most cases it doesn't help. But don't let me put you off because it is so rewarding when a gamble pays big dividends.

Some day I would like to play as a one or two province minor and survive however that is a long way away but I can still dream.

Seriously good game if you like your grand strategy really grand!
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Endless Replay-a-bility mosty because of the variety in natonal ideas, not just starting possitions (I'm looking at you CKII) and also partly because of the constant game changing updates, making the game easier for France and harder for small and non-European nations.
Cracking game, especially multiplayer.
If you come from Total War, biggest change, aside from the level of realism, is having to accept that you can't take over ze world.

reviewText:
This was my first expedition into EU territory, and let me tell you that all the dials, buttons, modifiers and events are rather overwhelming at first. review:

You can pick any nation/american tribe you wish from 1444-1821 rule them from different aspects such as diplomacy millitarily and adminstrativly and instead of being a king in this game. instead you ARE the country with kings growing from
becoming heirs and heirs growing to be kings each king with different stats either they can be diplomatic or adminstrative or a war mongerer. heirs can have weak claims on the throne so people you have royal marriages with might go to war to inherit your throne and it can be the other way around you taking their throne.

you can't go to war with anyone you wish as you need a cassus belli (reason) going to war without a reason   will greatly make you suffer as other countries might form a coalition on you

(trust me i went to war on an african minor for no reason then THE ENTIRETY OF NORTH AFRICA and arabia went to war against me.)

and the money system in this game is great you get income from multiple things like trade or tax etc and that money can help you recruit regiments of armies or building stuff and you can gift money to other countries so they like you.

there are diplomatic and adminstartive and millitary points that you gain through adminstratives you can use theese points to get ideas for example you can colonise the new world from the new world idea.

OKAY I WILL STOP NOW THIS IS TOO COMPLICATED.

what matters is:you wont like this game if you are a casual gamer or an rts gamer from games such as command and conquer, this is a Grand Strategy game if you like the total war series you will like this. although this is much more complicated and will take months to get used to the basics.

plus there is a mod that lets you play from 51 ad all the way to 2015 and beyond meaning you can pick any country from 51 ad to 2015. romans mongols etc etc

Pros:
-level of detail
-diplomatic system
-mods like the one i mentioned
-level of replayability
-The amazing orchestral sound track
much more

Cons:
battle system.
few glitches

Rating is 9 for me. add one if you are a paradox fan (sadly i only knew them from this game.)
subtract two if you are not a fan of the grand strategy franchise.

Aaand post.

reviewText: If you're like me, a history fanatic with tons of time to kill after the finals, your'e gonna love this game so much that all that you do is playing all day with your breakfast and dinner. It runs pretty well on early 2011 model of MacBook Pro but it occasionally jumps out and I don't know why. The scattered retreat feature is totally ridiculous but besides that it's good. The graphics is one of the best in the games of the same genre, and the music is truly masterpiece. The game mechanics is the most simple one among it's Paradox Brothers so don't be afraid by those overwhelming texts. Personally I learned some Latin with Global geography out of this game and since it doesn't have Chinese version, I feel my English skills have also been blessed. If you're planing to buy some games in Christmas, this game is an ideal choice. And if you're gonna play it, just remember don't invade Russia in winter, or fight Sweden with the same size of army--you need to triple your army and let all of your soldiers tell their mothers that they love them, in both cases.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Russia colonizing Australia because screw Great Britain, Sweden ruling Northern Germany and Canada because screw Great Britain, Rebelling as the USA (although not exciting as the real War for American Independance) because screw Great Britain, Create the world's largest trade hegemony as Portugal because screw the Netherlands for a change, or Byzantium re-emerging from a near-dead with the help of Poland to kick the Ottoman's butt. What's not to love about totally messing up history?

However, this is more than your average strategy game. If you're coming from the Civ camp over here, you're going to have a hard time. Trading, diplomacy, and war are a lot deeper here from other strategy games. I reccomend watching a let's play on YouTube after playing the tutorial, otherwise you're gonna suck at this.

All in all this is a great game for experienced strategy masters with great paths towards alternate history. Once you play it any other non-Paradox game will seem extremely slow and boring.

reviewText:
My take on this game :

Pros :
(+) Great simulation of Europe, Holy Roman Emperors, and the wars in between.
(+) Great simulation of New World Exploration. While we somewhat knows where is continental America, this is somewhat fixed in a New World DLC.
(+) Great simulation of Europe technologies. The technologies are also explained in a historical context.
(+) Good simulation of warfare. In addition of tactical battles, one can also won by engaging naval blockades, trade embargoes, and such.
(+) Good simulation on politics. Declaration of war is not that simple, you have to obtain a reason : whether it is a different religion, reconquest, etc. The mechanics of War Exhaustion, Stability, and Aggresive Expansion enable careful warfare and not all out map painting.
(+) Each big nation have their own ambition and mission. For example : Brandenburg to form up Prussia, and later Germany.

Cons :
(-) Sometimes your allies make such bad decision. Such as waging a 20-years war with a HRE/France for one pitiful province. Or wage 10+ years war that consumes manpower and increase war exhaustion for one tiny land.

This game is a historical simulator, not 100% accurate but still put history in context.

reviewText: Great game but not for everybody. If you enjoy numbers and micromanaging minutiae, and if you don't have anything serious to do in real life for the forseeable future, give it a try. When describing it to friends I typically draw parallels between alcoholism or other serious addictions, but that appeals to some poeple.\n\nI've honestly learned a lot about geography and history from the game. With a little imaginiation it feels like you're rewriting history with your own spin, and you can do it over and over again with hundreds of nations.

reviewText: A masterpiece of the Grand Strategy genre. You play as a wide selection of nations in the timeframe of 1444 to 1821. You have to take care of your economy, people, neighbours, diplomacy, religion and military while the rest of the world either wants you dead or torn apart. Find allies, and crush the baguette, remove kebab from Europe or stop Russia from annexing Crimea 400 years before Putin was even born. It's your choice. And if you ever get bored of the main game, there are great expansion packs that can squeeze some more hours, even when your playtime is in the thousands. And the modding community is alive and well too. A very good buy if you like the genre, and a great one if you enjoyed Civ.

reviewText: This was my first strategy game. When I first started, it was all so confusing. I stared at menus blankly, watched youtube tutorials, played through in-game tutorials. Could this really be the most accessible strategy game Paradox has to offer? Yes; and it's also one of the best expreinces I have ever had in my gaming life. I've spent entire days playing, watching the years go by. How am I going to deal with France? Should I ally Austria? THERE IS NO WAY I'M GETTING INVOLVED IN THAT WAR SCREW YOU AUSTRIA *declines call to arms*. These are some the burning questions I've asked and loud statements I've shouted during my time playing EU4. I played my first game as France. Easiest country in the game bar none. I got better. I played as Venice. Got better. Soon it wasn't about winning" or even doing well
date: it was about proving to myself that it could be done. Can I form the Netherlands as little Friseland. Yes
recommended: I can. Can I beat back the Ottomans as Byzantium? NO
hoursPlayed: NOT THAT. But through each failure I learned. Through each success I learned. I learned about the time period
voteText: I learned how to strategize
helpfulPercent: I learned how to accept defeat
votesHelpful: I learned the joys of winning an impossible war
votesTotal: and I learned that I loved strategy games. Thank you Paradox
votesFunny: and thank you Europa
commentsCount: for teaching me."

reviewText:
This game is an extremely good game once you get use to it. I highly recommend that you do the tutorials first, the game can be very confusing and complex, time is essential to succeeding and creating your empire. With over 100 hours of playing, I'm still not the best at the game, it takes time to finally figure things out. So I only recommend this if you're willing to be confused for a while until you learn the basics and than the complex stuff.


In my opinion, there are a few countries I would recommend you playing as if you're a newbie depending on what your goal is.

If your goal is to make a lot of money, then I would suggest either Venice or The Hansa, or any other merchant republic country. Venice & The Hansa have access to some of the best trade nodes in the game, giving you a reasonable amount of income, but also their ideas I believe do help a lot. (Don't quote me on it, haven't played as em, just heard about em)

If your goal is to create a military empire, I would suggest France for the most part, due to their traditional ideas, and the fact that they have a brilliant army at the start of the game. Giving you an advantage over your rivals and enemies, but time is your enemy, as France has some powerful countries as rivals, such as Austria, Burgundy and sometimes Castile.

Overall, a brilliant game with great mod support. There are some things I wish were there, just to make it much better.

reviewText:
After a game play with ironman mode of CK2, I think currently, EUIV is still the best game among Paradox games despite the fact that patches after patches, byzantine players, normad players and some other ppl who are struggling for their achievements all suffer through each updates.
Comparing with CK2, the game is more predictable: you don't need to worry about the massive revolts which are tirggered whenever your monach dies, nor do you need to deal with the massive aztecs, mongols who have no attritions. War score and military acess rules make the war more realistic. It's much more friendly for achievement players in this sense and only drives you mad in rare occasions.
Comparing with VICII, the learning curve is shorter. As long as you know how to manage your national ideas and understand all those modifiers, you can just get through it quickly.
For the new players, starting without ironman is a nice choice. A castilian compaign will let you understand the general mechanism of the game including vassals, personal unions, crusades and colonization. A moscow game will give you some ideas of the technology group and none catholic countries. An australian compaign will introduce the mechanisms of the HRE and diplomatic power.
If you are a fan of map/history, it would be a nice choice for you.

reviewText:
I just played a little, but it was a cool game
...
A sandbox game with infinite possibilities, just pick any nation in the world and make your own destiny
Wanna steamroll every poor soul of Europe as France? Check
Wanna (try to) survive and thrive as a small nation such as Georgia, Kongo or Serbia? Check
Wanna shape the history of mankind with your mighty empire of (insert any random nation)? Check

pros:
- Never ending game fun, you can play it for months nonstop and still want more
- Funny events
- Historical start-dates with historical countries in a historical history
- Better than Civ V
- Cooler than Civ V
- Multiplayer! Now you can also backstab the AI AND your friends!
- Beautiful terrain maps and other cool map stuffs
- Incredibly hard/funny/cool/interesting achievements
- Coolest mods of the block (yeah Skyrim, better than yours)
- Good music

cons:
- Hard to learn, if you are dumb, don't play it
- Not a balanced game, so most countries aren't funny to play at all
- Comets
- Backstabbing and treacherous AI (just like your multiplayer friends)
- End game boredom

So WTF are you waiting for dude? buy it, play it, don't stop it. And buy those expansive DLCs, they are gold

reviewText:
While I definitely wouldn't reccomend this when it was released, it's actually a good game now. Unfortunately, Paradox are money grabbing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and you need DLC for it to be enjoyable, so I would only buy this when it's on sale. Here's some opinions on different aspects of the game:

Warfare: The AI is way too eagre to take attrition. I'm talking about 20k soldiers sitting on a fort which needs 6k to cap. I'm talking about 30k sitting on their 25k supply capital. The AI loves to sit around doing ♥♥♥♥ all while their army dies. Now, it's been about 2 and a half weeks since the last DLC, so I'd expect the game to be pretty playable right now, but you can observe your allies being utterly useful a lot of the time. You may think this doesn't matter if you're reading this review a while in the future, but just be warned that when Paradox releases a DLC, the game is usually broken and will be quite buggy for weeks.

Economy and Colonisation: The whole trade flow" thing is great
date: and helps bring more meaning to colonisation through bringing tons of American and Asian goods to European markets for sweet sweet ducats. However
recommended: it also limits your expansion to specific regions

Edit: To clarify and come across as less spiteful, I, after thousands of hours wonder where the slavish kow-towing to the HRE comes from. There's even a non-toggleable dedicated UI element to them for their mini-game (dull as dishwater but you're -supposed- to care about it for some reason). See, if the series was set in Europe alone, full stop, this would have merit, but the whole world is opened up and yet somehow the Great Mughals or Ming (two examples) are supposed to care about a mini-empire far far away (Austria, default country of interest sooner or later, wherever or whatever you may be playing).

I have never understood this virtual hapsburg Shrine nor want to anymore. After 2600+ hours, I'm finished with the corporate money grubbing as a principle. HoI4 and Stellaris will pass me by too *shrug*.

reviewText:
FOUR HUNDRED HOURS...(edit: closing on 600 hours)

I haven't spent that kind of time on a stategy game since Civ IV. In a nutshell this is easily one of the best strategy games available at any point in the history of gaming.

Still reading? Ok. Thanks...let me make it worth your while.

I've played EU, EU3 and EU4 and this is the best of the series. The other games engaged me for 30, 50 or 60 hours. That's not bad but they never entirely grabbed me. This one is simply a better game than anything Paradox has ever released. The new Clausewitz engine renders this game beautifully. For those worried about the multitude of DLC packs, don't be. The base game plays beautifully and it feels complete. I only purchased the DLC well after I had 100 hours into it. Some may find the DLC worth it. I certainly did. But if you don't get it you're still buying a complete game.

So what makes this game good? Options and choice without complexity. EU4 is the epitome of every action has an equal and opposite reaction". Sure
date: you can play as a massive warmonger and try to gobble up everyone. But then you'll have to deal with the internal unrest and your neighbors banding together to take you down a peg. You can play as a nice neighbor and not attack anyone but then you'll have to deal with keeping major allies happy in order to watch over you. You'll have scenarios where lifelong allies of yours attack each other and you'll have to decide which one to back.\n\nDo you build up? Do you build out? It's all up to you. You can take France or the Ottomans and try to dominate the world. Or you can take a tiny country and just try to survive. And there's no "victory" in the game. Whether or not you won or lost is your call
recommended: not some arbitrary game decision. Meanwhile
hoursPlayed: you're balancing military
voteText: political ramifications
helpfulPercent: gold
votesHelpful: your provinces
votesTotal: technologies and a host of other factors. It's a lot to juggle but it's not overwhelming.\n\nThere's a learning curve here
votesFunny: but the new engine makes everything more accessible than ever. Thus while some people have been put off by the complexity of this series in the past
commentsCount: this one is actually fairly easy to get into. Now for someone who is entirely new to the engine it's going to take some time to learn your way around. It's not a typical strategy game where you can rush your actions. You have to take your time
column16: plan your actions perhaps decades in advance and then be ready to strike at a moment's notice. It's wonderful fun.\n\nThere aren't any large flaws with EU4
column17: which is one of the highest compliments I can pay a game. It is highly recommended for any strategy gamer's library."

reviewText:
This game is the pinnacle of grand strategy. Through exploration, colonization, conquest, trading, and diplomacy you will lead your nation to great glory or utter defeat. Play any country through the age of discovery, the protestant reformation, and into the age of classicism.

This game is a must have if you are a grand strategy fan or even just a history buff obsessed with the time period. though not completley historically accurate it is very authentic, and as it is a sandbox game as you play it gets less and less accurate but its possible you may pick up some history and geography.

Although its predecesors were overtly complex, I believe Paradox Masters of Grand Strategy have found a good balance of detail intricacy and accesability.

Now buy this game and lets play! It has steam works so you can jump right into multiplayer with no hinderments. Get started today you will spend hours clicking away tweaking your country and taking over the world.

reviewText:
This game was once great.

But that changed. It changed with the recent patch, I can no longer support this company or any of it's endeavors because of what they're doing. What are they doing? Well. Let me just paint a picture.

Before Common Sense. Provinces had no way to upgrade their base tax or things such as that without constructing buildings. You had no limit on the amount of buildings you could construct. Forts were nothing more than a defensive bonus to your provinces.

But with this DLC which patched in all of it's mechanics into the base game. Your provinces are now upgradeable! Huzzah! You can put investments into the development of the province to increase it's base tax. However, the buildings are now restricted base on how much development you have in your provinces.

Now. That'd be all fine and dandy if all the good parts of those changes weren't hidden behind a paywall.  Activating forts to prevent your bordering provinces from being taken? Nope. Pay up first buddy! Investing in development so you can improve your economy and have more than two buildings per province? Pay up!

I renounce my loyalty to Paradox as a whole. And will be seeking a refund if possible.

reviewText:
I love the game. In my opinion the game is one of the best strategy games of all time.
Gameplaywise it is quite unique.

I still can't recommend buying it...

____________________________________________


DLC:
Yes, I know that this is a review for the base game. However I think it is important to know about dlc and dlc-politics before buying a game.

important note:
Till now  8 major dlcs have been released for the game. Those dlcs are usually accompanied by a patch, which brings changes for everyone. But if u want to have access to all possible gameplay elements, if you dont want to stumble accross something like 'need to own XXX dlc to YYY', if you want the game to feel truly complete, you will have to buy atleast those (debatable). All other dlcs solely add new music and unit modells to the game, which do NOT influence gameplay. See eu4wiki for details.

Allthough the release of a new dlc every few months means that the game gets more content,
it has its downsides besides the need of cash:

Bugs and unbalance. Usually every major dlc brings new gameplay mechanics or radical changes. With them bugs come; the new mechanics are rarely balanced. Therefore one or two hotfixes follow every patch. Which can give you the feeling of having bought something incomplete or not fully tested.
Savegames. Whenever (or mostly) new dlc is released you will have to take special actions, if you want to continue a game and not start over again. You probably will have to do this before starting the game, otherwise your savefiles will be corrupted and your savegames will be lost. It will NOT matter, if you buy the new dlc or not, because the patch that accompanies the dlc will break the savefiles. A single run in this game takes many hours, therefore this is very important to know.
features. Be aware that features added in dlc, may later be changed, moved to available for all or even completely removed.
____________________________________________


What kind of game it is?
The game itself is a sandboxy grand strategy wargame set between 1444 and 1821. Your job is to take over the role of the ruler/rulers of one of the countless nations of that time period and lead said nation to glory. Besides 'glory' there is no fixed goal. You choose your own goal. You can play as Spain and explore and conquer the (or a random (dlc required)) new world. You can play as China and colonize America or conquer Asia. You can play as Austria and reform the Holy Roman Empire into one state. In case you are good enough, you can even conquer the whole world. The choice is yours!

pro:

overall deep and interessting gameplay
nearly infinite amounts of content and not completeable game (or atleast thousads of hours)
sandbox game
interessting period
contra:

very difficult to learn for new players
gameplay mechanics are not always explained in the game and tooltips are often misleading or wrong
ai gets bonuses (more diplomats, more money, ...)
ai sometimes behaves unforseeable or just weird (allies may 'betray' you without any warning)
bugs stay around for a long time while constantly new bugs turn up and others get fixed
savegames get corrupted by patches/are incompatible with new patches
multiplayer (unstable). Many players seem to have problems with connection in mp.
luck based. For example there are random events throughout the game. While many of them add flavor to certain nations, they are all random and you can get screwed by them. Battles partly include luck.
The Gameplay is considerable poorer in times of peace. Which is a problem, because bad luck (for example with events) can force you to stay at peace for a long time.

(Dlc can be viewed as good or bad based on what I wrote before.)


At this moment I have played the game for nearly 1000 hours and will most likely still play it for hundreds of hours. Like I said in the beginning I love it. I bought all of the major dlc at or close to realease, except the latest (Mare Nostrum, out 3 days, I will probably buy it at some point). Which means I spent about 140€. At this point, after almost 2 and a half year, this game feels like an early access title.
That feeling and the sum led me to the insight that i can NOT recommend buying the game, allthough I love it and buying dlc now or at sale would be way cheaper. Sure it is possible to enjoy the base game, but it will feel incomplete.
There is literally no other game where I could tolerate said things.

reviewText:
Having been a long time player of Paradox games, I'd have to say this is one of the most fun and polished titles they have developed so far. This game suits all your grand strategy needs and creates challenging situations through new mechanics such as aggressive expansion and coalitions. For people who complain about the learning curve of Paradox titles, I'd recommend this as the best game to pick up first. It might well be difficult to learn, but it is interesting enough to keep you entertained and incredibly rewarding when you get the hang of things.

The replayability is also a huge plus (as it is with most Paradox games). The amount of countries to play is fantastic and there is a huge amount of variables that mean that two games are rarely the same. Adding to this, the amount of mods trickling out extend and improve the games playability as well as Paradox's expansions which aim to improve how 'lesser' countries play out.

If you're interested in grand strategy games, it's a must-buy.

reviewText:
This game is broken and the developers are genuinely evil people. No, I see you looking at my playtime. No

Seriously, I don't know why I tolerate it. I mean, I really don't know why I take this so well. It's just...darkness induced apathy, I suppose. But really, this cashgrab ransom of a game is probably the worst example of the gaming industry I can possibly think of, and I almost love it.

Here's the short version:
They broke the game, and the only way to un♥♥♥♥ the game is by buying a DLC.
The DLC is called Common Sense.
For 20 dollars

I have to admit, I busted out laughing, hard, when I saw that. I can't believe I'm saying this, but I genuinely enjoy how terrible these developers and publishers are. They are so evil it's actually ♥♥♥♥ing funny.

Basically, long and short of it, ever since 2013 the developers have been holding the game hostage. Every couple weeks, they'll 'update' it, consisting of several dozen 'features' that you have to pay for. 20 bucks each DLC. If you do not have this dlc, that's okay. You just can't use the features. I mean, sure, the entire game is now balanced around them, and you're ♥♥♥♥ed unless you buy it so you can upgrade your ♥♥♥♥, but it's freeeee!


This means that unless you buy every DLC at the moment it's released, you can not win. Full stop, it doesn't allow you to win. It's a fee to pay game at it's worst; the publisher is rotten and everyone involved has given up any artistic or even mechanical vision they had for it. Do not buy it. Do not buy anything paradox has published. They will stop at nothing to try and force you into buying 20 dollars worth of nothing every couple weeks.

reviewText:
I want so badly for this game to be fun, because it's such a cool concept. But I've been disappointed every single time I load it up and give it another try. It could be so much better.

Here's something to understand if you're thinking about trying it: It's more like Risk than Civilization. It's a game about conquering territory, not building an empire. War is the only practical thing there is to do. If you're not at war, you're just gonna be staring at the screen for hours waiting for numbers to go up.

Nothing will make sense to you the first time you play this game. The amount of help provided is very limited, and the UI is very confusing. Icons without meaning abound. Numbers and modifiers are given without explanation of what they actually do.

If you stick with it, you'll discover that fighting and conquering land is kinda fun. Troops are moved around in real-time, which makes it feel realistic. I'm sure I would have more to say on combat if I knew more about how it worked, but of course, it isn't explained very well. 90% of the fun in this game comes from looking at the territory you own and thinking Ahh
date: look at all the land I own now."\n\nThe massive amount of provinces and nations in this game is really

hoursPlayed: and every one is playable

reviewText:
8/10 - This is a GREAT game.

+tive Points - It is EXTREMElY addictive and enjoyable for long hours, there is literally never a moment with nothing to do; whether it be war, building infastucture, stabilising your economy or advancing technology. Especially fun with many friends on multiplayer; this is when the game is incompareable to anything else, it IS grand stratergy. You really get drawn in and you get stuck to its sticky bosom of pure enjoyment. You really feel you're building an empire, and there are so many playable nations you literally can replay the game thousands of times, for thousands of hours. It is also one of the most easily modable games on Steam, with many mods adding even more greatness to an already great game.

-tive Points - If you're new to stratergy, this game throws you into the deep end and you will spend a LONG time getting to grips with the multitude of mechanics. Battles, although fun and challenging, can be repetitive with the same animations and tactics, a little more variaty and interactive-ness is needed in my opinion. Multiplayer HAS A LOT OF ISSUES. Although it is the best part of the game, the servers have many issues, with players frequently and randomly disconnecting or not even being able to join a lobby. A game in multiplayer may take time to get going, but when it does, it is AMAZING!

Overall, if you love stratergy, this is a requirement. If Paradox can sort out multiplayer servers and issues, you would be looking at a 10/10 game here, but these issues do make the game frustrating at times.

reviewText:
Europa Universalis IV is a very simple game, in theory. You control a nation, from 1444 to 1821, and lead it to world dominaton or commercial dominance or whatever else you want to do, using your military and diplomats to get what you want.
In practice, it is incredibly complicated. Every country not controlled by a human is being run by the AI, even if you can't see them. Every other country will react to changes in the political climate as they happen, generally resulting in very unexpected endings. Each country will have its own opinion of yours, influenced by things like who your enemies are, how much land you took in recent wars, what religion your country practices, and even whether or not they just want you dead to begin with.
There are a variety of ways to make other countries see more highly of you, just as there are ways to make them want you dead even more than they already did. You can annex smaller neighbors that think highly of you, or you can go to war and dominate your neighbors instead. Each country has a goal, and these goals will change dramatically over the 380 years you have to act. Each country has its own bonuses; the Merchant Republics of Venice and Novgorod are in a great position to amass large quantities of wealth, if they survive. The giants of Muscovy and Austria can easily dominate anyone who tries to oppose them.
The question is, what is it you want to do? The Byzantines, driven to near destruction by the Ottomans, can still be led to the restoration of the Roman Empire by anyone willing to lead them there. The Swedes, in the Kalmar Union under Denmark and sure to be annexed, can remove the Danes from their throne and become a colonial empire under the right leadership. There are, without exaggeration, an infinite number of possible directions you can take this game. The El Dorado expansion pack and its custom nation designer only reinforces this; build a Muslim republic in Lithuanian land, conquer Russia with it, and then become an Islamic Russia. Set up a Jewish empire in Ireland and conquer England. Whatever. Go do it.
Now, I assume, you're thinking Ok
recommended: but how well is it executed?" Flawlessly. The incredibly complex diplomacy system gives every nation a mind of its own; every country will forge alliances and make enemies by themselves
hoursPlayed: and you can manipulate that with ease to ensure a network of powerful alliances with which to conquer the world. The military system
voteText: equally deep and complex

reviewText:
After many years of Civilsation and other similar strategy games I thought it was time to play something a bit deeper!
Saw all the excellent reviews for EU IV and gave the demo a go. Glad I did as this is an amazing game.
If, like me, you are put off by really complicated strategy games then please persevere with it! Once you get the hang of the game engine it is a thing of beauty.
There is so much depth and historical detail in this game that it is astounding how much work it must have taken to create!
The graphics are really good for a strategy game and the interface becomes very easy to understand after a few games.
Do not be put off by initial difficulty, it is defintely worth the effort!
The extra DLC also shows how much love went into this game and continues to go into it.
Put simply, if you want to truly control the world or think of yourself as Machiavelli this is the game for you :)

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game to any strategy buff. It is better than Total War and Civ by far IMO due to its design.

It is real time and may seem complicated to play with the overwhelming interface, but it really isn't. Their are no resources like food or wood to micromanage for example, all you have to worry about on the surface is stability,unrest and your income. Other things like war exhaustion and aggressive expansion come into play also during conquest.

The diplomacy in this game is the most functional I have ever encountered in a strategy game and has real consequences.You can know based on your diplomatic score how nations will react to you most of the time which comes in very handy. For example, when deciding to declare war on a common foe unlike Total War or Civ you will know beforehand if they will join you or not based on various factors, you will also know whom you will be up against.

Diplomacy is essential to your survival, and can really make or break your game. You are not likely to survive or progress in the early to mid stages of the game if you do not form alliances. If you are too aggressive and ♥♥♥♥ off the wrong people, coalitions will form and attack you and force you to give up territories.

The game is real time and you can adjust the speed to speed up during slower times in between conquests or to slow down to micromanage your troops and events at a pace that is comfortable for you.

This was a breath of fresh air for me coming from Total War Rome 2 where campaigns can take 40 hours or more to complete. Depending on how fast you set the time it is possible to finish a campaign depending on your goals in around 10-12 hours. Additionally, all nations are available to play each presenting the player with a unique challenge and experience.

This game is a sandbox game, so there are no victory conditions" unlike in Civilization or Total War
date: which gives you total freedom to pursue Ironman achievements
recommended: focus on building a trade empire
hoursPlayed: colonize
voteText: lead a crusade
helpfulPercent: overthrow the Holy Roman Empire
votesHelpful: become the Emperor and many more. For example
votesTotal: you can play as The Ottomans who have the best starting position in the game or you can play as The Knights of Rhodes who have nothing but a tiny island and are in one of the worst starting positions in the game
votesFunny:
being threatened by The Ottomans for a different challenge.It is totally up to you. There is nothing more satisfying than triumphing as a small nation over larger foes through skill and diplomacy.

Every game plays out differently due to the AI RNG which allows for almost infinite replayability.
There are many achievements to get that are very rewarding and challenging if you play in Ironman mode.

DLC:

There are quite a few DLC that are essential to getting the full experience out of the game. They are good in that they add new features that are blocked behind a paywall in the base game but bad in that you have to pay extra for them. The reality is that most of them are not essential to the game but Art of War and Common Sense should be the ones any player has at a minimum.

The DLC can be found on sale typically during steam sales for very cheap or you can go to 3rd party sites to find them for an affordable price if you don't want to pay full price.

The learning curve is steep and I am still learning things so it is highly recommended that you search the wiki and watch YouTube videos to learn the fundamentals of the game as the tutorial is seriously lacking.


Overall as a complete game. I cannot say enough good things about it. It is currently IMO the best grand strategy game on the market even with the DLC business model.


10/10"

reviewText:
I couldn't recommend this game more, while it's not for everyone; if you like strategy games, you're sure to like this.

It allows you to establish an empire, with the main focus being on European colonisation and expansion, but you can do it as almost anyone, for example you could colonise America as Castille (later Spain), conquer everything as Russia or maybe attempt to conquer the world as the Ryukyu islands.

The game isn't just your normal conquest game, it has lots of micromanaging and you must be careful what you do.

Cons;
VERY steep learning curve
Can get tedious
Paradox manages to mess up every patch for a day or so

Pros:
Once you've learnt it it's loads of fun
No game is the same
Mods on Steam Workshop

So, if you ever wanted to conquer France, but realised that you're not allowed to do it in real life, then here's the solution to your problems, do it in the most fun strategy game in ages!

reviewText:
This game is amazing. It's so thorough and realistic! You simply cannot build a massive empire without worrying about stability, and even when you do begin to get big, you have to worry about coalitions, other massive empires! It always keeps you on your feet in some way no matter how powerful you become.

Features I love tremendously:

Modding Community. I can't express how awesome the modding community is for this game. My favorite mod is the Extended Timeline. I created a massive Germanic Empire covering europe following romes demise during the migration period(I replaced the roman empire, and more, hehehe). I even took on the mughals (which formed from parthia.

Frequent Updates and Patches. This just shows how much Paradox Entertainment cares for their games to keep them entertaining. The new Art of War expansion added so much! 900 extra provinces, 150 new countries, new rebellion mechanic, better war mechanics.. that is just the tip of the Ice berg!

http://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/showthread.php?810805-1.8-Full-Patch-Notes


Diplomacy. This is tremendously well done. You can literally manipulate the throne of another kingdom and force them into a Personal Union (only if your Christian, since the AoW update). Diplomacy dictates every corner of this game. If you expand too quickly, your neighbors will see that as 'aggressive expansion', and possibly form a massive coalition against you. This is an amazing game-balance mechanic, as it prevents big empires from going on a conquest rampage. You are forced to form alliances no matter what nation you start as, least you fail the game in the short run, and if not the short run, then the long run.

War. The war.. It's so amazingly realistic. It makes you feel like your fighting against another nation like they would in that time period (With crusader kings being even more accurate in this regard). Every single day begins to count during a war (real-time after all, no joke) The way a war is fought is heavily dictated by the supply limit a province can provide your troops. A smart enemy can fight a war of attrition against you, making you lose thousands of troops each month while you flee.

Expansion. Yes, I love how the expansion isn't dictated by what you occupy, but what your warscore is in a single war. This boost the realism level to almost as high as it can go. Historically it was impractical, and logistically impossible to conquer a huge empire in one war. You would have mass rebellions, and administrative problems to say the least. Couple this with the over-extension mechanic, and that is where the realism really blossoms. Even when you conquer a small section of an enormous empire, and you still have to deal with massive instability and revolt risk!

Honestly, this review only covers a small fraction of the awesomeness of this game. There are so many equally awesome features that I have not covered in this review, and I'm lazy. If you are a fan of conquest games, you should buy this game undoubtedly - unless you prefer the style of CK2 over EU4 (I like both).

The devs continue developing the game and add new stuff, which is awesome, but each time a new version comes out- they add another DLC (usualy costs additional 15$), and to play with full experience you need the DLCs- else the systems and mechanics will work crappy and technically the new versions add nothing.
The devs release new versions each 3 to 5 months so technically you have to pay some 45$ a year to continue playing- ofcourse you can remain on old versions, but after hearing about the new stuff you feel that it's missing.

I do recommend the game, since it's really awesome game, but pay attention that there are these overpriced DLCs before you start playing.

reviewText:
Europa Universalis 4, the game so good you'll develop E-U-4-ia is a grand strategy in which you select a nation and try your best to not get conquered by France, the Big Blue Blob.  Even if you're some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little Asian nation, don't worry, BBB's-a-comin' sooner or later.  Probably later.

To me the real time the game shines is during multiplayer, where all of Europe can jack each other off in Woodstock-class hippy peace time, dividing up the world so nobody is sad and teaming up in ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t alliances against anyone who would try to provoke actual conflict.

With frequently-added expansions to the game that aren't nearly as trivial and cash-grabby as certain other studios (not going to namEAnyone) your experience becomes even greater over time.  Speaking of time, if you have under three hundred hours in the game I consider you to be casual scum.

So good luck, Tengri bless, and support DDRJake for Dictator of Earth 2016.  I'd join his coup, why wouldn't you?
