reviewText:
I have written this review to negate some of the unfair reviews that give this game a negative score. I do admit the last couple of dlcs have been lackluster (Mare Nostrum, and The Cossacks specifically), however if the dlcs are not giving enough content for their price do not buy it. It is your choice if you decided to pay fifteen dollars for a lackluster dlc and the opinon of the dlc should not be the determination for the base game's score. There are many excellent expanions released for eu4, that in my opinon would negate any negativity from the last two expansions.

The base game in itself is a game that I would reccomend playing. I have played many hours in vanilla itself. The game is a grand strategey with much more depth than games like the civ series. You play a nation of your choosing, and attempt to do as best as you can with it. Some nations are easier than other due to this game being based on history ( France is stronger than a Native American nation). The game is like a puzzle, many hours will be spent figuring out alliances, truces, aggressive expansion opinon modifiers, religion to be able to conquer the world without destroying yourself in the process. There are national ideas and events which make many nations unique in their playstyle, and there are idea groups which you unlock which give you various bonuses that can further specalize your nation. One thing that is amazing about this game is whenever something happens that could ruin my game it is always my fault, and it is something that you can learn from and choose to never make the same mistake again.

The DLC is one thing that is essential to review, there are a lot of dlc for this game. Don't judge the game on the the price of every dlc combined, many DLC are just cosmetic and music addition packs. There are a few dlcs that are expansions to the game ( Res Publica, Wealth of Nations, Conquest of Paradise, Art of War, and Common Sense) which in my opinon are all essential and worth every penny spent on them. If you are scared of the hefty base price of these dlc combined, don't be scared as they frequently go for sale up to 75% off, so you can get all these expansions for less than 10 dollars if you wait for good sales. If you wait long enough the recent dlc (Cossacks and Mare Nostrum) will probably be given huge sales as well.

I would not reccomend this game who are looking for quick fun, this is a game you sit down for hours at a time to plan and fail, and then restart the game over, and then fail but do a little better, then fail fail fail, and then you may finally perfect your game and do way better. A single playthrough can take around two weeks to get through, while it may take a lot of time it is really satisfying when all goes to plan and you acheive your goals. I would reccomend this to people who enjoyed civ games but are unsatisfied by the lack of depth or strategey in those games, I would reccomend this to people to have enjoyed playing Risk. In fact I reccomend this to most people I have met.

tl:dr

A lot of reviews are being unfairly negative about this game to their opinon that the recent two expansions are overpriced for the content they delivir (I share this sentiment). However this game has a lot of other expansions that are really good that balance this out. The vanilla game is in itself really good. Don't expect a fast game, or something that you can just pick up and play I have played around 700 hours and am considered a intermediate player. While a bit diffcult to start it is an amazingly satisfying game when your plans come to fruitation.

10/10

reviewText:
Europa Universalis IV was published and developed by Paradox Interactive (a publisher and developer of niche games)
Initially I want to point explicitly out that this game is for grand strategy game lovers and history geeks (including myself ;) )

However, I'll start with the positve aspects of Europa Universalis IV.
EU4 offers you a variety of nations to play. You can play with >260 natioms.
It also has got a dynamic economic system that you can manipulate with trade ships or owned land in the certain trading node. I also enjoy the military and geopolitical factor in EU4 because its the best part in my opinion.
The actual combat is pretty unique because unlike in the Total War series, it is like a board game. You have to pay a lot of attention to various factors: you have to pay attetion on your tech level, the terrain (NEVER underestimate the terrain), the morale of your troops and their discipline, if you play smart you can kill a larger army by simply having high morale, good tech, disciplin and a terrain advantage on the other side if you act stupid and attack an enemy that has got these advantages you'll possibly send your loyal troops into a deathtrap. This can be frustrating but it isn't the games fault your decision your fate.However, this is just one way annexing it in a peace deal there are more ways to get your empire to grow: gain territory through a personal union (royal marriges pay of) or vassilize the country and integrate it into your grandé nation.
Another important game mechanic tool is the diplomacy you can ally, sabotage, create/join a coalition , support your allies. There's a lot more you can do it's just an insane amount of opportunities in order to make histroy as YOU like it.
Now I'll come to the best part of that this game has to offer: the community, the community is smart, backstabbing :) and very into EU4.
In addition to that there's also the genius modding community creating ahistoric mods, game improvements, essentially everthing that you search in the mods you'll find it!

Now to the negative parts:
There are not a lot of negative parts so i'll keep it as short as possible.
- Not very stable multiplayer
- localization issues with non english versions
Well thats all i have to complain about at the moment.

I would totally recommend you buying EU4 if you're into history or/and strategy games because it will suck you in and steal all your free time.

Thats it, if you dis/liked this review please comment it and I apoligize for spelling/grammar failures as I'm no native english speaker.

reviewText:
Europa Universalis IV is a Grand Strategy Game developed by Paradox Entertainment. The game allows you to take control of a country from the time period of 1444 until 1820 (An official save converter for Crusader Kings II can push this date as far back as 867). The country pool you draw your selection from is vast, ranging from future world powers like England, Sweden, and France to Native American and Meso-American tribes like the Shawnee, the Cherokee, The Aztecs, and the Inca. Keep in mind that every country is not created equal; Western Countries have a much easier time as opposed to those with Eastern or Tribal cultures. Westernizing as a tribal group is always a must; you will be crushed otherwise.


In Europa Universalis IV, the world is your oyster. Your goals are yours to define; Emergent Gameplay is very much a key point of the game. Do you restore the Byzantine Empire from it's single holding of Constantinople? Do you attempt to conquer the new world as the Ottomans? Or do you follow the historical path of your country, such as colonizing the New World as Spain or Portugal? All of these scenarios are able to occur in the game, and feel immensely gratifying when completed.


The Game plays like a charm, although I would recommend turning off Lucky Nations as they tend to skew the game in the AI's favour, with the game following the Earth's history a bit too closely. England, France, The Ottoman Empire, and Spain all usually end up becoming the defacto world powers with Lucky Nations set to historical. With Random Lucky Nations the game becomes a bit more interesting, but I would still say to turn this setting off.


The game also has a large learning curve, though the tutorial in the game helps you get the basics of the game down. The rest, however, is up to you to verse yourself in. You will lose. Often. But those often are not like those other strategy games such as Civilization. These losses teach you all kinds of interesting facets of the game. In no time you'll be ensuring the nation you're about to crush has no alliances with a more powerful Nation, or that they're currently weak thanks to fighting rebels that you spent some ducats to support.


Overall, I heartily recommend Europa Universalis IV. Though it's hard to get a grasp on the genre, Grand Strategy Games never fail to provide an entertaining, thrilling ride throughout a possible alternate timeline.

reviewText:
With a large range of nations to play and a complex diplomatic system, EU IV manages to live up to it's previous title, EU III.
The map is much more detailed now and the trade system is much more robust than in the previous game, even offering you a visual representation of the trade routes and trade areas.

Thge religion system is also improved. For example, playing as a catholic nation, you can vote bishops by using your religious influence on the Papacy and the bishop may even become the Pope.

The military system is also improved a slightly more detailed. It offeres a much easier to manage system wehre you can easily split your troops, move them or even recruit. There are also more types of rebels and even flags to represent them. They are much more powerful in comparison to EU III and if you're not careful they can really screw over your nation.

The player has more control over colonization and how it works making you feel more in control of your empire. You can send colonists to a specific place (depending on your technologies) and you can either try to work together with the natives or send down an army and slaughter them all.

The technology 'trees' have more to them now in comparison to the previous title and uses a point system to unlock different technology types. The point system is where the game unfortunatly the game fails. It offers three types of points, Administrative, Diplomatic and Military. All these are harnessed over time but the speed they are harrnesed at depend on your monarch and the advisors you have. With these points you can unlock new technologies, reduce your over-expansion, increase stability,decrease inflation and etc. This system makes the game feel way too arcadish, and you'll find yourself finding all sorts of ways to aquire these points but they make no sense realistically. the Europa Universalis series was very popular for it's somewhat realistic approach to things, making it more of a historical sandbox simulator rather than a Star Craft like RTS except on a huge map, trade and diplomacy. It is also far less challenging to achieve certain things in the game like form a commonwealth or a nation (but that's not always true, some are still fairly challenging).

All in all it is still an enjoyable game and it's even more enjoyable if you're playing it with the MEIOU and Taxes mod which offers a much more robust religious system, more historicaly accurate map, general rebalances and much more.

reviewText: An Amazing game missing some of the key features which its predecessor had, but along with new game mechanics not having them seems only trivial. The new trade system allows players to engage in wars for trade and also enables dynamic fluctuations between profit. The new coalition and aggressive expansion system means that players have to be more careful and watch who they are angering. The coalition system allows players to stop nations who outgrow their respective borders, but can also be turned on the player if aggressive expansion gets too high with surrounding nations. These features make this the best installment in Paradox's Europa Universalis series, and i would highly recommend this to anyone new to paradox games or even seasoned vets of Europa Universalis.

reviewText:
With a large range of nations to play and a complex diplomatic system, EU IV manages to live up to it's previous title, EU III.
The map is much more detailed now and the trade system is much more robust than in the previous game, even offering you a visual representation of the trade routes and trade areas.

Thge religion system is also improved. For example, playing as a catholic nation, you can vote bishops by using your religious influence on the Papacy and the bishop may even become the Pope.

The military system is also improved a slightly more detailed. It offeres a much easier to manage system wehre you can easily split your troops, move them or even recruit. There are also more types of rebels and even flags to represent them. They are much more powerful in comparison to EU III and if you're not careful they can really screw over your nation.

The player has more control over colonization and how it works making you feel more in control of your empire. You can send colonists to a specific place (depending on your technologies) and you can either try to work together with the natives or send down an army and slaughter them all.

The technology 'trees' have more to them now in comparison to the previous title and uses a point system to unlock different technology types. The point system is where the game unfortunatly the game fails. It offers three types of points, Administrative, Diplomatic and Military. All these are harnessed over time but the speed they are harrnesed at depend on your monarch and the advisors you have. With these points you can unlock new technologies, reduce your over-expansion, increase stability,decrease inflation and etc. This system makes the game feel way too arcadish, and you'll find yourself finding all sorts of ways to aquire these points but they make no sense realistically. the Europa Universalis series was very popular for it's somewhat realistic approach to things, making it more of a historical sandbox simulator rather than a Star Craft like RTS except on a huge map, trade and diplomacy. It is also far less challenging to achieve certain things in the game like form a commonwealth or a nation (but that's not always true, some are still fairly challenging).

All in all it is still an enjoyable game and it's even more enjoyable if you're playing it with the MEIOU and Taxes mod which offers a much more robust religious system, more historicaly accurate map, general rebalances and much more.

reviewText: This is one of the greatest grand strategy games out there along with CK2. Basically you pick any country (that exists) in the world from near the end of the Middle Ages in 1444 A.D. to 1821 A.D. at the end of the Napoleonic age and you play them until the game ends at 1821. Everything is historically based and of course there are hundreds of countries to pick from meaning you'll spend hours and hours of this game just playing a new and different country each time. Each game length varies, but I'd say at least a full twenty four hours each if you really immerse yourself. Every single experience for each country is not the same, as most countries have unique ideas that affect the way you play each country, and they all aren't equally powerful, meaning different approaches and strategies have to be used in order to be successful. Want to change history? You could save Constantinople from the Turks and restore the Roman Empire, or you could even take over Britain as Ireland. The possibilities are endless. Downsides? Not much, however the game and UI can be overwhelming to some at first.

reviewText:
Came back to play this after a long time, had nearly 200 hours in it. Found that the updates to the game completely unbalanced the game. I rather like to play as micronations struggling to survive against the odds, I get that's hard, that's why I like it. But the updates have made this completely impossible, not playing as an already large nation is asking for a screwjob. I'd like to compare that frustration to Dark Souls (I have it on console) but at least Dark Souls has a strategy too it that can help you overcome the odds, this is just asinine. Worst off I've tried to reset the game to versions such as 1.11.4 and 1.12.2, the earliest versions that supported the El Dorado DLC and not the recent updates, they crashed every time I started a game. Uninstalled, no question about it I have no reason to continue playing this game. I'm just happy I got my moneys worth out of it before all this happened.

If you want details about the updates themselves they go as follows:

Provinces instantly fall if they do not have a fort, putting a strain on your forces to constantly recapture them if you are doing anything more than chasing down one enemy army.
Buildings (such as forts) have over doubled in costs, costs micronations I like to play as cannot afford. There seems to be no boost to cash flow.
Each province with a fort costs 1 gold to maintain, in large nations that adds up quickly in small nations that puts you in debt.
I'm not honestly sure what else they added, I saw this and I was pretty much done. Military conquest was supposed to be engaging, difficult, and rewarding not a pointlessly frustrating hassle.

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing






But seriously, I love this game! :D

reviewText:
Europa Universalis IV (V. 1.12.2.0)

Europa Universalis IV is a historical simulation / grand strategy game developed by Paradox Interactive. First released almost two years ago back in August 2013, the game continues to receive regular updates and instalments in the form of DLCs, the most recent of which - Common Sense - was released in June 2015. Starting in the year 1444 and ending in 1821, the game gives you the chance to rule any nation in the world during the era of Colonisation, when the nations of Europe explored the world in search of new land and riches.

This review will focus predominantly on Gameplay due to how important it is to the game, but because of the word limit I will not be able to cover everything.

Gameplay

In the game, you are given control of any country you choose throughout the world, in any time period between 1444-1821. Being a grand strategy, there are a lot of things to focus on. One of the most central features of Europa Universalis IV is technology, which you must upgrade throughout the course of the game by generating and spending points (commonly referred to as monarch points), which are gained each month in-game and are split into three areas: Administration, Diplomacy and Military. Points are generated based on the skills of your leader and your leaders advisors, who cost gold (in-game ducats) to employ, but along with generating points can also give other bonus modifiers to your nation. You are given the ability to focus on a specific area if you deem it necessary, at the cost of losing points in the other categories.

Technology is split into the same three categories as the points, and have up to thirty-two levels. As you progress, being ahead in technology gives you bonuses over other nations in the game, at the cost of the next technology level costing more because you're ahead of time. Being ahead in technology, as well as other things, contributes towards your Game Score, which merely gives you a ranking to see how well you're performing in comparison to other nations.

Where you start geographically in the game decides your nation's technology group, of which there are a few. The further away you move from Europe, upgrading your technology costs more monarch points, which means it takes longer. As a balance however, the lower your technology group, the more monarch points you can generate and store. When playing as a non-Western nation, you have the ability to 'Westernize' once you border a Western nation, on the condition that you're behind on at least seven levels of technology.

After reaching the fifth level of Administrative Technology, you can unlock an Idea Group in one of the three main areas of Administration, Diplomacy and Military, which you can progress along by spending monarch points. Every nation in the game starts out with National Ideas, which give extra bonus modifiers to your nation and can be unlocked through completing ideas in Idea Groups. Once Idea Groups are completed, some can be paired together to set National Policies, which can give you extra bonus modifiers at the cost of a single monarch point in that policy's key area (e.g. an Administrative policy costs you one Administrative point monthly in-game to maintain).

There are many other things you will have to spend your monarch points on, so spend them wisely.

There are other points which you will have to focus on: Stability, Prestige and Legitimacy and Power Projection. Stability is the overall strength of your nation, and if it is positive, that will give bonuses to your nation. If it is in the negative, it will give penalties. Prestige is how noteworthy you are, and has the same impact as Stability. Legitimacy is the strength of your ruler; the less Legitimacy your ruler has, the less authority they have. Power Projection is how imposing you are towards other nations, and this depends on how active you are against your nation’s Rivals, which you can choose throughout the game.

Alongside all of this, you will have the help of various invisible individuals who you can send around on various tasks. You will have Diplomats who you use to improve relations and form alliances, or even fabricate claims and declare war on nations. You will have Merchants which you use to steer trade and collect trade from various nodes, and Missionaries to help convert land. A key feature of the game can be utilised through Colonists, who – once unlocked – can be sent to colonise regions like the Americas and Africa.

Finally, you must build your armies independently (based on Infantry, Cavalry and later Cannons) and hire generals to lead them. Navies are also built independently, with various units built for specific purposes. Provinces can be improved with various buildings that grant bonuses, and the more Development a province has the more buildings you can build in them. Random events will occur from time to time, which can either have positive or negative effects depending on what decision you pick. Considering all of this – and other aspects I haven’t even covered – I’d recommend that players take a good long while to explore the mechanics of the game before becoming too ambitious in their aims, particularly as the User Interface does have a few hidden yet incredibly important pieces of information players should keep an eye on.

Graphics and Sound

The world map is displayed beautifully, and features many useful and varying map modes to give you all the information you might need to digest from just a quick glance. Decorated with beautiful terrain and sprites, it’s easy to spend hours just surveying the map without any in-game time actually passing. The soundtrack is also quite enjoyable to listen to, and in Paradox’s usual style of thinking outside of the box, the addition of heavy metal music to the soundtrack makes playing the game even more enjoyable, if not just for the music itself.

Three Pros and Cons

Pros:

+ Perfect for fans of history, and a must have grand strategy for any armchair general or wannabe dictator.

+ Every game is unique, so you can play again and again with many different outcomes.

+ Workshop-supported; community content gives the game even more replay value.

Cons:

- Hard learning curve; in-built game tutorial is severely lacking.

- The User Interface can be incredibly overwhelming at first, and a lot of crucial numbers and modifiers are hidden in the tool tips with no obvious pointers as to where they are.

- Certain features depend on whether the player owns a particular DLC, which narrows down the possibilities with the base game.

Conclusion

Europa Univeralis IV is the physical definition of Grand Strategy; limitless possibilities await you as you lead your chosen nation to a glorious future. Whether you follow history or change it is up to you, and the goals of the game are your own. A definite must-have, the game will have you hooked for hours and is a momentous challenge, but I can guarantee you that it will not be a waste of time.

Finally, you must build your armies independently (based on Infantry, Cavalry and later Cannons) and hire generals to lead them. Navies are also built independently, with various units built for specific purposes. Provinces can be improved with various buildings that grant bonuses, and the more Development a province has the more buildings you can build in them. Random events will occur from time to time, which can either have positive or negative effects depending on what decision you pick. Considering all of this – and other aspects I haven’t even covered – I’d recommend that players take a good long while to explore the mechanics of the game before becoming too ambitious in their aims, particularly as the User Interface does have a few hidden yet incredibly important pieces of information players should keep an eye on.

Graphics and Sound

The world map is displayed beautifully, and features many useful and varying map modes to give you all the information you might need to digest from just a quick glance. Decorated with beautiful terrain and sprites, it’s easy to spend hours just surveying the map without any in-game time actually passing. The soundtrack is also quite enjoyable to listen to, and in Paradox’s usual style of thinking outside of the box, the addition of heavy metal music to the soundtrack makes playing the game even more enjoyable, if not just for the music itself.

Three Pros and Cons

Pros:

+ Perfect for fans of history, and a must have grand strategy for any armchair general or wannabe dictator.

+ Every game is unique, so you can play again and again with many different outcomes.

+ Workshop-supported; community content gives the game even more replay value.

Cons:

- Hard learning curve; in-built game tutorial is severely lacking.

- The User Interface can be incredibly overwhelming at first, and a lot of crucial numbers and modifiers are hidden in the tool tips with no obvious pointers as to where they are.

- Certain features depend on whether the player owns a particular DLC, which narrows down the possibilities with the base game.

Conclusion

Europa Univeralis IV is the physical definition of Grand Strategy; limitless possibilities await you as you lead your chosen nation to a glorious future. Whether you follow history or change it is up to you, and the goals of the game are your own. A definite must-have, the game will have you hooked for hours and is a momentous challenge, but I can guarantee you that it will not be a waste of time.

reviewText:
Updated on 23.12.2014. In short, the three major expansion have fixed most of the issues with the game, and added a massive amount of extra content and flavour.

Review:

An improvement over the already excellent 'EU3: Divine Wind' in almost every way imaginable.

- For those interested in the genre, this is probably the best place to start: Excellent tutorials (by Paradox's standards, at least), less unnecessary abstraction, but all the depth of a PDS game. You'll still fail miserably a few times before fully figuring the game out, but that's always been part of the fun in these titles.

So ye, if you're new to grand strategy, get this.

- As for 'us' veterans? Improved mechanics across the board, trading that makes sense, more challenging AI and Ironman mode make this a worthy sequel to EU3.

The biggest change from EU3DW is the monarch point system that replaces the budget sliders and magistrates. A welcome change, in my opinion, as now you can't just adjust your sliders a bit in the early game for high stability and fast military tech. Monarch points are used for national ideas, tech, buildings, national decisions, even peace treaties.

The highly limited amount of monarch points earned per month force the player to really think about his actions. No more spamming buildings at max magistrates and never touching the sliders.

This system does have slight balance issues: military tech is always a better investment than military ideas, for example, and the fact that your ruler's skills play a major part in your monarch point income can screw over large portions of a playthrough. Fall behind in military tech because of an idiot king?
lol ok, Prussia is going  to eat you now.

Other small problems include the infrequent revolutions and apparent ultra-stability of large AI nations. In my three finished campaigns, [strikethrough]only a handful of American nations ever managed to gain independence, and I've never seen a Revolutionary France. Small sample size, yes, but it does seem like large empires are a bit too stable at the moment.[/strikethrough] These happen far more often now. Colonial nations revolt quite often and the revolution mechanic makes seeing revolutionary nations far more common.

The UI is much better this time, being closer to CK2's than EU3's, but the panels and the font are still far too small at 1920x1080. Fortunately, there is a fix to this in the Steam workshop, another great addition to the game.

AI has seen quite a few improvements as well, especially in diplomacy. Every nation now has a limited amount of diplomatic relations they can maintain, and the AI does seem to understand the mechanic quite well, cutting ties with nations because of shifting interests, and seeking new allies as the game progresses (instead of picking 3 allies at the start of the game and sticking with them, like in EU3).

Cascading alliances are not a problem anymore, as infamy was replaced by an aggressive expansion relations hit to all nearby nations. AE going too high leads to the AI forming coalitions: defensive alliances that do what cascading alliances were supposed to.

Overall, the AI nations seem far better at waging war; effectively pursuing hostile armies, splitting up to siege multiple provinces at a time, exploiting river crossings to crush larger forces, etc.

EU4 > EU3  Divine Wind. [strikethrough]Only thing I actually miss from EU3 are the overseas territory names (ie. Portuguese Africa, British Caribbean)[/strikethrough] Conquest of Paradise adds this back in.

- How is it as a standalone title?

A bloody brilliant game, and miles above any non-PDS strategy game in depth, scale and complexity. It also looks very pretty, so that's good.

I was a long-time Total War fan, before being introduced to EU3. Now, even Empire: Total War feels far to simplistic.

Expansions:

The Conquest of Paradise

- Colonial nations form when you have enough colonies in an overseas region. Similar to vassals, but pay tariffs instead of taxes. A pretty cool mechanic, though I do miss being able to micromanage every single colony.
- Randomized New World. Not too exciting. Terrain generation is really odd, and looks like a random map seed from Age of Empires 2.

The Wealth of Nations

- Revamped trade system is great.
- Trade companies are like colonial nations in the East. Cool system, but has the same problems CN's have.
- New diplomacy options are great. Transfering trade power, new casus belli. Great additions.

Res Publica

- More flavour for Poland and the Dutch. Not too exciting, but highly recommended if you want to play those nations.

Art of War

- More diplomacy options again. Excellent additions like supporting rebel CB, fight for subject CB, war reparations.
- Autonomy system added in the patch is great, as is the new revolution mechanic.

reviewText:
If you are in general a fan of war, history, strategy, trade or Europe, or more specifically European warfare, the strategy of European warfare, the history of the strategy of European warfare, or especially the history of the strategy of European warfare, politics, trade and nationhood during the Age of Exploration, this game should pique your interest. To get a taste of the game, I'll just tell you what happened in my last campaign:

After conquering the Zapotecs and Mayans over the course of a century long series of conflicts, the Aztec Empire experienced a golden age of peace and prosperity where mountains of wealth were stored away for future use. This all ended when the European powers suddenly colonized and cornered the Empire on both sides: the Portuguese to the south at the Yucatan and the Norwegian to the north on the Gulf of Mexico. Immediately Portugal attacked. To prevent its eminent destruction by a more technologically advanced nation, the Empire converted to Catholicism, became Defender of the Faith, westernized and went to war with the Protestant heathens to the north. Over the course of three wars with Norway, the Empire successfully converted its people to the new religion and actually obtained more influence in the Papal Curia than Portugal had. Despite the Aztecs conquering Protestant territory up to the mouth of the Mississippi, successfully converting the entire country to Catholicism, and having good trade relations and national reputation with Portugal, the Portuguese eventually attacked again, sacked Tenochtitlan, bankrupted the Empire and stole away the Yucatan peninsula from its rightful owners. It seems that in the trifecta of war (God, Glory and Greed) Greed has been and always will trump what is religiously right.

If you learn anything from that it should be playing non-European countries is hard. But even on the hardest difficulty, this game is very fun and will result in some amazing stories.

Also! If you do decide to buy this game, please don't forget to play with the music on. The soundtrack will make you feel much more badass when you play. Trust me.

reviewText:
Europa Universalis IV
The Sequel to the critcally acclaimed Europa Universalis III did not disappoint.  With a variety of a new features mounted on a brand new Clausewitz 2.0 engine the game is much more smoother and less clunkier in most aspects, having streamlined alot of the chores into a simple click of a button. Detaching for a siege,Patrolling,rebel supression etc is just a click of a button away as compared to EU3 where you had to manually detach men for a siege for example.

As the name might suggest,the scale is colossal spanning 7 conintents and 5 oceans (barring Antartica) the world is your playground. There is no clearly defined objective or motive , it is all up to you ,the player. Playing as England you can try to beat france in the hundred years war and rewrite history. If your a fan of the Romans, you can try to restore the roman empire. Take the balkans back from the ottomans and push them out of asia minor,maybe expand into western europe and reconquer the city of Rome. You can even explore a randomized new world with the Conquest of Paradise Expansion. The possibilities are endless.

However,as with any games,there are definitely bugs and flaws. The Protectecrate System as of now is essentially useless,they do not fight in battles and only give you trade power. Your Protectecrates system to benefit more off you than you do off them. Colonial Nations are abit buggy as well,other colonial nations can declalre war on your colonial nation without even calling you to arms, so if for example a 20 province colony of portugal declares war on a 5 province colony of yours,you can not do anything except watch them eat your colony up unless miracously they win that war.There are still many more bugs which i have not pointed out. but you get the idea

That being said though Europa Universalis 4 is still definitely worth getting , it's replayability value is practically endless and if you have Crusader Kings 2 and the CK2 to EUIV converter , you can start a game in CK2 and Continue all the way to the end of EU4 and maybe even Victoria If there is a converter.

9/10 Rating

reviewText:
Base Rating 9.5(With Major DLC)

All Right many of my friends were very nervous about purchasing this game after all it is 40 dollars or your local equiavalent.
I was the first of our group to purchase this because I was told it was more empire managment than another paradox game that you might be famaliar with Crusader Kings 2. I Enjoyed that game and it was my first paradox game that I didn't rage quit in 1 hour.

So the basic thing that made me buy it was that I heard it was similar to CK2 but it was in my favorite time period except more empire management. Now I had watched videos about the game but I was still incrediably nooby and died a crapload of times thanks to my refusal to play large nations. I feel like theres a huge learning curve and lots of planning and proper execuation to properly reach your goal. At times it will be filled with complete disparity as events such as Peasant's war will hit you at the absolutley worst time. First time it happend I was playing with a friend multiplayer and it begun after I literally just seconds after I finished a massive war with Austria. My friend and my ally tried his best but was also exhausted because he had aided me in the previous war. If things couldnt get worse my treasury was depleting fast so I had to disband most of my heavy ships. To make matters even worse England(Allied with Austria) seeing my weakness delcared war on me and so did bunch of idependent rheinlander states. Mircaulously me and my ally prevailed and I got revenge on all those who wronged me and invaded the british isles.

All this brings me to the point that this game is filled with possibilities and that I only sctrached the surface with this review. Therefore I must oblidge on fullheartly recommend this game for anyone who loves Grand Strategy and Historic games.
GoodLuck and Godspeed!

reviewText:
One of the very best grand strategy games out there. If you have a thirst for world domination and do not like people to tell you how to get there, then this game is for you!

You get so many avenues of approach it will become a whole thesis just to list them all. It's about building your country, keeping your friends close and enemies closer, its about building up your army and staying ahead in technology, so that your armies get that edge they deserve! Its about the buildup to the perfect coup de gras.

One thing this game does well if to present choices without dumming down the mechanics, in fact it is my experience that with new expansions they ad or expand on gamemechanics making the game more and more immersive, and thus giving the player even more ways to move ahead. This means however that the game has a steep learning curve for new players. You can expect to spend the first 10 or so hours to get a good grip of the basics and still have trouble beating your larger neighours. But the satifaction when you first manage to take down France is immense!
To help you, there is a very good and fleshed out wikipage, that for the most part gets updated almost instantly after new expansions gets released.

For me, and this is the reason ive reached this many hours on the game, is multiplayer. Going into multiplayer with friends or finding players through the paradox forums, will add a whole new game experience to the mix. Every area of the game gets improved, war, diplomacy etc. The multiplayer part does have a few problems though, as with most paradox games, the game can get unstable after a while, and out of sync problems can and will happen. Slower computers or computers with unstable or slow internetconnection will also present a problem, but can for the most part be solved with slowing down gametime.

I recommend this game because there are so many fun hours to be had. Because the way you want to play it, is entirely left up to the player, and because Paradox seens genuinly interested in improving upon this game with its now many expansions.

reviewText:
Europa Universalis IV is grand strategy at its best. It is epic in scale and depth, with literally an entire world to explore over three of the most dynamic centuries in history. It manages to create a completely believable world that pays homage to the forces that have shaped history while simultaneously giving you the opportunity and tools to reshape it in anyway you please.

The sheer number of features and mechanics at work can be a bit overwhelming. The interface certainly takes some getting used to as you are inundated with bewildering amounts of information. However, as you gradually learn to master these features and mechanics, you crave every bit of scrumptious data as your actions both affact and are dictated by then. This is a refreshing stand against the plethora of games that continously dumb down in order to appeal to mass audiences.

The real weakness in this game is suggested in the name. While the European playthroughs are as fleshed out and fun as you would expect, those in other regions of the world are noticeably less so. Certainly, the developer is slowly working to address this problem. Through patches and expansions, places like East Asia and the Americas will become more fully developed with more nations and features. Still, the general focus on Europe hurts the otherwise immersive game experience.

Completely recomended for strategy gamers, cartophiles, and lovers of history. 9/10

I was the first of our group to purchase this because I was told it was more empire managment than another paradox game that you might be famaliar with Crusader Kings 2. I Enjoyed that game and it was my first paradox game that I didn't rage quit in 1 hour.

So the basic thing that made me buy it was that I heard it was similar to CK2 but it was in my favorite time period except more empire management. Now I had watched videos about the game but I was still incrediably nooby and died a crapload of times thanks to my refusal to play large nations. I feel like theres a huge learning curve and lots of planning and proper execuation to properly reach your goal. At times it will be filled with complete disparity as events such as Peasant's war will hit you at the absolutley worst time. First time it happend I was playing with a friend multiplayer and it begun after I literally just seconds after I finished a massive war with Austria. My friend and my ally tried his best but was also exhausted because he had aided me in the previous war. If things couldnt get worse my treasury was depleting fast so I had to disband most of my heavy ships. To make matters even worse England(Allied with Austria) seeing my weakness delcared war on me and so did bunch of idependent rheinlander states. Mircaulously me and my ally prevailed and I got revenge on all those who wronged me and invaded the british isles.

All this brings me to the point that this game is filled with possibilities and that I only sctrached the surface with this review. Therefore I must oblidge on fullheartly recommend this game for anyone who loves Grand Strategy and Historic games.
GoodLuck and Godspeed!

reviewText: I'm in love with this game. Europa Universalis III was one of my favorite strategy games and easily my favorite Paradox game, and EU4 is an improvement across the board, a strictly better game in every way it's different. A much improved interface, far easier to understand at a glance, and way more interesting strategic decisions to make at any given moment. EU4 is without caveat good enough to legitimately stand toe to toe with the Civilizations and Total Wars of the world. I can feel secure saying that this is probably going to be the best strategy gaming experience to be had all year, in a year Brave New World came out and Rome 2 is coming out.  If you enjoy strategy games, you will enjoy this game, get it.

reviewText:
One of the best Paradox creations of all time. While for experienced in RTS games players it is noob-friendly, it can be actually quite confusing and complicated for new comers to understand the concept and purpose of all the factors included. As the name of the game says, it's mainly concentrated in Europe as the timeline in the game goes from the years 1444-1821. The game adapts many features and it's very comfortable for the user to actually control everything, the simulation of economy, war and diplomacy is really well done and there are many unique features and events that could help you even more. While there is a tutorial, for the new-comers it won't be the best of help. The game is purely built on historical map (almost entirely correct) and after you pick a date and begin with a country, you can change the concept of history entirely.

Although mentioned that the war mechanics were good, they aren't exactly ideal. or sometimes realistic. There aren't any really factors that influence the combat other than the terrain, manpower and.. some rolling dice. You can accept it as a kind of a chance game or even gambling. The diplomacy branch is good on the other side. There are special points - Administrative, Military and Diplomatic points and each of them have their sole purpose. I won't go exactly in detail about them, but there are special 'people' - Diplomats, Merchants, Missionaries and so on. This is the mechanic I really like, as it's a defining point of the game and it can perform many actions. Another factor is the monarch (or the ruler), and he's a pretty valuable in the game too. There are many skipped parts but this is the main look of the game and its welcoming to the people.

TL;DR: Like Strategy? Like History? This is the game for you. Give it a go!
9/10

reviewText:
If you enjoy managing a country to global super power status this game is for you. Being a grand strategy game virtually every aspect of your country is up to you such as trade, internal conflicts, war, manufacturing and more.

You begin by choosing any possible country existing betwen the years of 1444-1821. Japan, Spain, the Ottomans and more are all options and all have different gameplay mechanics. You may choose to try to unite the Holy Roman Empire as Austria,  conquer the seas and trade as the Netherlands, rule the new world as Spain or Portugal or simply take over the world. As time goes on you collect Monarch Points whch can be spent to improve technology or take idea groups to help your country excel in different aspects.

One of the main goals in EU4 is taking over the world (or at least carving out a little piece of it for yourself). This is personally one of my favorite parts of the game as it is very different from games such as civiization. Politics are deeply involved and alliances, vassals and other factors come in to play. Furthermore different war justifications can be used (casus bellis) which allow different goals and outcomes for the war as well as different effects on your neighbours. Combat itself can be compared to Risk. The player does not take part in battlefield tactics, but with the careful positioning of different armies and aquisition of military technology and ideas can win the war for you. In that way it is quite a bit deeper then Risk.

The player can also turn towards more diplomatic solutions for growth. Managing a navy to take a larger part in trade, colonizing the new world or marrying into other royal families are all examples. Trade specifically is set to be improved with the up coming Wealth of Nations" expansion. These aspects all require your attention to help your country flourish and have various mechanics to amke them fun and satisfying.

However there are particular downisdes. One being the steep learning curve. If you rush into the game like I did you may feel overwhelmed by the plethora of buttons and menus. This is expected being a grand strategy game. However don't give up. There are in game tutorials as well as amny online ones. Furthermore most buttons and figures displayed contain tool tips to explain their meaning. After a few hours of play you should be able to have  basic understanding of the game. Once you make it past you can find a deep and satisfying experience. Be prepared for failure though.

Another aspect may be that of balance. The game is not meant to give an equal difficulty experience to each country to imitate history. If you play as a 1st Nations tribe youll find yourself falling behind on technology and with inferior units. I would recommened beginning with a western powerful nation (France
recommended: ) and moving on to others for a challenge.\n\nIn summary if you can get past the learning curve this game is loads of fun and great for any strategy lovers."

reviewText:
One of the very best grand strategy games out there. If you have a thirst for world domination and do not like people to tell you how to get there, then this game is for you!

You get so many avenues of approach it will become a whole thesis just to list them all. It's about building your country, keeping your friends close and enemies closer, its about building up your army and staying ahead in technology, so that your armies get that edge they deserve! Its about the buildup to the perfect coup de gras.

One thing this game does well if to present choices without dumming down the mechanics, in fact it is my experience that with new expansions they ad or expand on gamemechanics making the game more and more immersive, and thus giving the player even more ways to move ahead. This means however that the game has a steep learning curve for new players. You can expect to spend the first 10 or so hours to get a good grip of the basics and still have trouble beating your larger neighours. But the satifaction when you first manage to take down France is immense!
To help you, there is a very good and fleshed out wikipage, that for the most part gets updated almost instantly after new expansions gets released.

For me, and this is the reason ive reached this many hours on the game, is multiplayer. Going into multiplayer with friends or finding players through the paradox forums, will add a whole new game experience to the mix. Every area of the game gets improved, war, diplomacy etc. The multiplayer part does have a few problems though, as with most paradox games, the game can get unstable after a while, and out of sync problems can and will happen. Slower computers or computers with unstable or slow internetconnection will also present a problem, but can for the most part be solved with slowing down gametime.

I recommend this game because there are so many fun hours to be had. Because the way you want to play it, is entirely left up to the player, and because Paradox seens genuinly interested in improving upon this game with its now many expansions.

reviewText:
If you are in general a fan of war, history, strategy, trade or Europe, or more specifically European warfare, the strategy of European warfare, the history of the strategy of European warfare, or especially the history of the strategy of European warfare, politics, trade and nationhood during the Age of Exploration, this game should pique your interest. To get a taste of the game, I'll just tell you what happened in my last campaign:

After conquering the Zapotecs and Mayans over the course of a century long series of conflicts, the Aztec Empire experienced a golden age of peace and prosperity where mountains of wealth were stored away for future use. This all ended when the European powers suddenly colonized and cornered the Empire on both sides: the Portuguese to the south at the Yucatan and the Norwegian to the north on the Gulf of Mexico. Immediately Portugal attacked. To prevent its eminent destruction by a more technologically advanced nation, the Empire converted to Catholicism, became Defender of the Faith, westernized and went to war with the Protestant heathens to the north. Over the course of three wars with Norway, the Empire successfully converted its people to the new religion and actually obtained more influence in the Papal Curia than Portugal had. Despite the Aztecs conquering Protestant territory up to the mouth of the Mississippi, successfully converting the entire country to Catholicism, and having good trade relations and national reputation with Portugal, the Portuguese eventually attacked again, sacked Tenochtitlan, bankrupted the Empire and stole away the Yucatan peninsula from its rightful owners. It seems that in the trifecta of war (God, Glory and Greed) Greed has been and always will trump what is religiously right.

If you learn anything from that it should be playing non-European countries is hard. But even on the hardest difficulty, this game is very fun and will result in some amazing stories.

Also! If you do decide to buy this game, please don't forget to play with the music on. The soundtrack will make you feel much more badass when you play. Trust me.

reviewText:
This is easily the greatest grand strategy game I've ever played to date. With constant mod support and even years of promised attention from the devs themselves this is truly a game that rivals any other of this genre. I don't think a strategy nut would feel complete without having this political simulator under their belt.

I bought this on a whim and 200 hours of play time later its not only still fun and fresh with every game I start, but is beyond my favorite game of all time.

reviewText: My favorite strategy game. The systems for the standard Military, Diplomacy, and Administrative aspects of leading a nation in a strategy game like this are all very robust, and challenge you to divide your resources and be the most effective ruler you can be. It is incredibly satisfying to change the course of world history through hard work and practice. A bit of a learning curve but in my first game I was able to become the most powerful nation in central europe by 1800.

reviewText:
Europa Universalis IV is a global grand strategy game covering the period from 1444 to 1820.  The game is complex and rich in detail.  It offers extensive replayability not only in the choice of nations (from the great nations of Europe or Asia, a small merchant state or a american / meso-american tribe) but the strategic path you take to build your empire. You can start with a great power such as France or England and carve a path of conquest thru Europe, or start  with a small merchant state and expand thru trade. Choose Spain and build an empire by colonizing the New World (and Africa and Asia), or perhaps start as the Incas and conquer meso-america.  The gameplay choices are endless.


The game does have a fairly steep learning curve and requires a fair amount of micro managing to build and maintain your empire.  You'll need to build relations, create alliances, establish colonies, protect your trade, create vassals, suppress revolts, arrange royal marriages, research different techologies, establish national policies and embark on military conquests while calling on your allies for support (and cursing them when they tell you to get lost).  And that's just a small sample of the myriad of decisions.


There is a lot of DLC available for the game.  Each expansion release coincides with a game update that introduces free new mechanics while the expansion expands those mechanics with additional features.  While the base game remains playable without the expansions, the full impact of the new mechanics is lost without the expansions.  That's  subjective and a matter of personal taste.  Additional DLC in the form of unit, portrait and song packs are simply a matter of choice.


Of all of Paradox's strategy games, this one is probably my favorite.  The incredible detail and broad range of options make this a must have for anyone who enjoys strategy games.   If micro-managing isn't your cup of tea, then give the game a wide berth.

As you can see from my accumulated playtime (1,288 hrs) the game can be really addictive

reviewText:
EU 4 is a great grand strategy game that has a lot of depth but is also approachable. Also, it manages to be an engrossing sandbox game while maintaining some historical flavor. Unlike the Civilization series, the hundreds of playable countries are quite different.

It has some problems  and I don’t approve of the changes that the DLC has made to colonization, but it is easily my GOTY for 2013.

reviewText:
Europa Universalis IV
The Sequel to the critcally acclaimed Europa Universalis III did not disappoint.  With a variety of a new features mounted on a brand new Clausewitz 2.0 engine the game is much more smoother and less clunkier in most aspects, having streamlined alot of the chores into a simple click of a button. Detaching for a siege,Patrolling,rebel supression etc is just a click of a button away as compared to EU3 where you had to manually detach men for a siege for example.

As the name might suggest,the scale is colossal spanning 7 conintents and 5 oceans (barring Antartica) the world is your playground. There is no clearly defined objective or motive , it is all up to you ,the player. Playing as England you can try to beat france in the hundred years war and rewrite history. If your a fan of the Romans, you can try to restore the roman empire. Take the balkans back from the ottomans and push them out of asia minor,maybe expand into western europe and reconquer the city of Rome. You can even explore a randomized new world with the Conquest of Paradise Expansion. The possibilities are endless.

However,as with any games,there are definitely bugs and flaws. The Protectecrate System as of now is essentially useless,they do not fight in battles and only give you trade power. Your Protectecrates system to benefit more off you than you do off them. Colonial Nations are abit buggy as well,other colonial nations can declalre war on your colonial nation without even calling you to arms, so if for example a 20 province colony of portugal declares war on a 5 province colony of yours,you can not do anything except watch them eat your colony up unless miracously they win that war.There are still many more bugs which i have not pointed out. but you get the idea

That being said though Europa Universalis 4 is still definitely worth getting , it's replayability value is practically endless and if you have Crusader Kings 2 and the CK2 to EUIV converter , you can start a game in CK2 and Continue all the way to the end of EU4 and maybe even Victoria If there is a converter.

9/10 Rating
